TopicTitle: Challenge: Lowest possible orbit around the sun without burning up!

Articles.Content:
Using less than 100 parts, I challenge you to get a low orbit around the Sun. My lowest orbit was 2km. Now, just try to beat that!

EDIT: Challenge closed. Too hard, plus people kept asking for proof.

2km in 100 parts would require a lot of patience.

Here's 1.5 million km in exactly 100 impatient parts:

Looking at my submission, I realize I could do much better: replace the mainsails with two stages of skippers, which allows converting struts to fuel. Mainsails need so many struts.

I could of course replace the triple LV-N setup with a single, but I was impatient: I couldn't tolerate much less than 1 TWR.

And had I properly calculated my burns, I could have ended with a circular orbit.

Close to the sun, I think even a single OX-STAT panel will fully power an ion engine

You don't need much so one option is to use nuclear to get close and switch to ion. Think I used 6000 m/s to get from LKO to low solar PE and 16.000 to circulate and lower it to 2km.

I remember around 25-30 km/s being required according to discussions in SunJumper's challenge in order to orbit low. It's very little difference between 1000km and 0km. You might as well be walking on the sun.
